articles.headline: Betting to Improve the Odds
articles.snippet: Companies are using prediction markets to funnel ideas from the work force.
articles.abstract: Companies are using prediction markets to funnel ideas from the work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORPORATIONS live and die by ideas, and many enterprises have used Web-based technologies, like blogs, wikis and social networks, to gather thoughts and hasten their way into new services, products and cost-saving steps.

articles.headline: Economy Has Become a Drag on Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: The gloom pervading the financial markets and the business climate has reached the land of innovation.
articles.abstract: The gloom pervading the financial markets and the business climate has reached the land of innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Housing prices in Silicon Valley remain defiantly high. New BMWs and Saabs cruise Highway 101. But for the first time there are signs that the current economic downturn is taking its toll on the country’s cradle of technology and innovation.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Brad Stone

articles.headline: As Torch Reaches San Francisco, It Runs for Cover Before Its Run
articles.snippet: The Olympic torch extravaganza could become a civic migraine in the face of potential protests against China.
articles.abstract: The Olympic torch extravaganza could become a civic migraine in the face of potential protests against China.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The Olympic torch arrived at the airport here from Paris in the wee hours Tuesday morning, exited out a side door and was escorted by motorcade to a downtown hotel. There it took a well-deserved break in a room complete with cable TV, room service and views of the city’s popular Union Square shopping district.

articles.headline: For Many, a Boom That Wasn’t
articles.snippet: In every other expansion since World War II, the buying power of most American families grew while the economy did.
articles.abstract: In every other expansion since World War II, the buying power of most American families grew while the economy did.
articles.lead_paragraph: How has the United States economy gotten to this point?

articles.headline: Ex-Fed Chairman Chides Current One
articles.snippet: Former Fed chief Paul A. Volcker criticized the Bear Stearns bailout at a meeting where officials acknowledged the downturn may be “prolonged and severe.”
articles.abstract: Former Fed chief Paul A. Volcker criticized the Bear Stearns bailout at a meeting where officials acknowledged the downturn may be “prolonged and severe.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest financial crisis in a generation  a downturn that officials at the Federal Reserve acknowledged in minutes released Tuesday might be “prolonged and severe”  is turning the traditionally reserved and omniscient central bank into an institution that seems to be in the throes of family therapy.

articles.headline: In Storing 1’s and 0’s, the Question Is $
articles.snippet: Digital data degrades over time, and it is unclear how best to preserve it — or how much it will cost to do so.
articles.abstract: Digital data degrades over time, and it is unclear how best to preserve it — or how much it will cost to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISTEN. Do you hear it? The bits are dying.

articles.headline: 2 Oil Firms Plan Alaska Gas Pipeline
articles.snippet: BP and ConocoPhillips joined forces to try to develop Alaska’s vast reserves of natural gas, saying they would spend billions to build a North Slope pipeline.
articles.abstract: BP and ConocoPhillips joined forces to try to develop Alaska’s vast reserves of natural gas, saying they would spend billions to build a North Slope pipeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two of the world’s biggest oil companies, BP and ConocoPhillips, joined forces Tuesday to try to break a longstanding deadlock over Alaska’s vast reserves of natural gas. They said they would spend billions to build a pipeline from the North Slope to feed energy-hungry markets in the United States and Canada.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Looming Deficit Impedes Federal Housing Agency
articles.snippet: The Bush administration and Congressional leaders are counting on the F.H.A. to rescue thousands of struggling homeowners, but the agency has financial woes of its own.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration and Congressional leaders are counting on the F.H.A. to rescue thousands of struggling homeowners, but the agency has financial woes of its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration and Democratic leaders in Congress are counting on the Federal Housing Administration to rescue hundreds of thousands of homeowners from foreclosure by helping them refinance from risky subprime loans to stable government-backed mortgages.

articles.headline: As Prices Rise, Farmers Spurn Conservation Program
articles.snippet: Farmers are taking their fields out of a government conservation program that pays them not to cultivate.
articles.abstract: Farmers are taking their fields out of a government conservation program that pays them not to cultivate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Out on the farm, the ducks and pheasants are losing ground.

articles.headline: Election, and Maoists, Could Transform Nepal
articles.snippet: Nepal’s elections on Thursday could bring the opportunity for the installation of a fully elected government.
articles.abstract: Nepal’s elections on Thursday could bring the opportunity for the installation of a fully elected government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal  With one vote on Thursday, this longtime Himalayan kingdom, wedged strategically between India and China, will have the chance to do what few modern nations have done: refashion its entire government.
